questions.question_text: The range of the function f:(-1,1]→R,f(x)=2−x is
questions.detailed_answer: The function f(x) = 2 - x is decreasing. When x = -1 (approaching from right), f(x) approaches 3. When x = 1, f(1) = 1. Thus, range is (1,3].

questions.question_text: The function f(x)=√(6/(x^2−x−6)), x∈D→R has a maximal domain so
questions.detailed_answer: The expression inside the square root must be non-negative: x^2 - x - 6 ≥ 0. Factoring gives (x-3)(x+2) ≥ 0. Solution: x ≤ -2 or x ≥ 3, or (-∞,-2] ∪ [3,∞).

questions.question_text: The graph of the function y=tan(πx/4) is dilated by a factor of 2 units from the y axis. The period of this transformed graph is
questions.detailed_answer: Original period of tan(πx/4) is 4. Horizontal dilation by factor 2 stretches the period to 8.

questions.question_text: Part of the graph of the function g is shown below. The rule for g could be
questions.detailed_answer: The period is π, so n=2. The graph is an inverted cosine shifted down by 1, so g(x)=−cos(2x)−1.

questions.question_text: For the function f with domain R, • f'(3)=0 • f'(7)=0 • f'(x)>0 for 3<x<7 • f'(x)<0 for x<3 and x>7 The graph of f must have
questions.detailed_answer: f' changes from negative to positive at x=3, indicating a local minimum, but since f'(7)=0 and the sign change is not specified around 7 in a way that indicates extremum distinctly, wait no: wait, for inflection, but actually from signs: decreasing to 3, increasing to 7, then decreasing after 7? Wait, f'(x)>0 for 3<x<7 (increasing), <0 for x<3 (decreasing to 3), >7 <0 (decreasing after 7), so local min at 3, local max at 7. But options: A local min at 3, D local max at 7. But the answer in solutions is B, stationary point of inflection at x=3. Wait, the condition is f'(3)=0, f'(7)=0, but for 3<x<7 f'>0, but for x<3 and x>7 f'<0? The bullet is • 7 3 and 3 for 0)( ' << < < x x xf • 7 for 0)( ' > > x xf which seems garbled, but from solution, it's stationary point of inflection at x=3.
